description:
The Radio Habana Social Club is an experience. Dada art, sangria to split, and and an all-ages hang all make this place exceptional, like a post-card from another era of San Francisco that we might be able to hold on to if we actually push back on gentrification. 

The average group here is a couple or two friends, splitting sangria and likely a bite to eat. The food isn't the star here, the ambiance is. We got the flan, which was fabulous, and the maker of said-flan was onsite drinking at the small bar. There is table service if you get food, or bar service if you don't. 

Highly recommend for anyone looking for a long night of conversation, art, and friends in a small space free from the SF tech-bro scene.
author: Molly H.

description:
This is NOT a Cuban place, decoration is hideous nothing like a Cuban place would be!

Most important, The FOOD is not Cuban either, tamales were Mexican tamales and microwaved, in fact all the food is microwaved, you can hear the microwave beeping!!!!!
author: Grester G.

description:
We stumbled into this place walking through the city. It was quirky and we gave it a chance. It is a hole in the wall, mom and pop kinda place, like literally, a mom and a pop, that's it. So yes, it is understaffed. Our food did take a while to come out, like other reviews said. 

Their decorations are......one of a kind. Not my cup of tea for sure..a bit creepy actually.  

The food were kinda cheap but subpar. Mole chicken was plain. The rice, black beans and salad that came with it were also pretty plain as well. The pupusas and samosas were not as bad. Samosas were really spicy though.
author: Veronica N.

description: Love the decor in this tiny Cuban joint. Food is good. There's a story behind all the wall hangings and pictures.
author: Madhu J.

description: Very cool decor but extremely average food and sangria was warm. Wouldn't do it again but worth a one time visit.
author: Yana Y.

description: Loved the vibe in Radio Havana and the food was delicious. They're open late which was very convenient - I hate having to settle when it comes to food late in the evening. The atmosphere made it more than a restaurant- it was an experience.
author: Austin S.

description: Love the ambience and the food is simple and flavorful. I recommend going here is a small group of 2 or 3 since it's a hole in the wall kind of place. Our server was a sweetheart. We had a pitcher of sangria which serves 2 pretty well and some house special pupusas for appetizers. I really liked their salad, the dressing was very refreshing.
author: Sneha P.

description: Came here with a friend, took a table and we've been kicked out after 5 mins. The owner (old lady), asked us if we wanted to order, I replied "we're waiting for a friend she'll be here soon", she told us it would be better if we order right away because we were holding the table. I immediately said "Ok then, we'll order". She didn't even let me finish and she shouted us to get out if we didn't were for ordering. I replied 3 TIMES: "I want to order now though, as you asked". She said "I don't care get out". Crazy? Rude? Definitely not welcoming. If your goal is to spend your Sat night and your money in a nice place, don't come here.
author: Elena M.

description: I gave this place 3 stars. One because it happened to be CASH ONLY and there wasn't no visible sign anywhere (outside nor inside), two because my food wasn't hot (but it seemed understaffed, so I didn't want to bother) and lastly because the older lady wasn't very welcoming or friendly. The food was very tasty, the sangria was great and the customer service from the man running the bar and taking food orders was good too!
author: Cyn S.

description: Cool little bar. Has plenty to look at with all the decorations on the ceilings and walls. Not for anyone freaked out by dolls. Lots of different dolls with mixed up body parts. I loved it.
author: Lolita M.

description:
I still like Radio Habana as a quirky bar and a good chill place to hang out.

But I do *NOT* recommend going here for the food, especially if you're hungry. The quality is fine, but you will wait forever for your food. They do have a very limited, small kitchen: one guy, one microwave, one stove, very little space. But I wish I'd gotten a heads up of the long wait when I ordered my food around 9pm and didn't get it til almost 9:45pm (on a Thursday night). I was really upset by the time I finally got my food.

There's also only one woman running the bar and taking all the food orders. They're just really understaffed and maybe just shouldn't serve food during the post-dinner rush.

See my photos as well for additional details.

DINNER PLATES
* Albondigas Legendarias (four mediterranean meatballs in sweet herbed tomato sauce. $9.95) - 4 stars
These meatballs were actually really good. They were textured, had plenty of flavor, and were in this deliciously tangy tomato sauce. The rice and beans fell a little flat, the rice being a bit loose and the black beans a little undercooked.

DINNER PLATES SPECIAL
* Pork & Chicken Sausage Pot ($10) - 3.5 stars
This was solid but the meat wasn't as flavorful as the meatballs. Same comment about the rice and beans as for the meatballs.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Quirky decor, and generally fun vibe. Super friendly hosts, which was great. Probably good for a beer or two, but also for the snapchat opportunities.
author: Vickram S.

description: Pretty good flavor but there were lipstick marks on my water glass and the food was lukewarm
author: Jasmin R.

description: I can't believe I've lived in San Francisco over 20 years and am only now discovering this place.  The good was amazingly tasty and really inexpensive.  So much eye candy...  The room is covered floor to ceiling with oddities and conversation starters.  And the service super friendly and service was quick.  I'm returning frequently.
author: Kim C.

description:
Small but quirky bar - great sangria and the Cuban food looks amazing, although I didn't get a chance to try it out. 

If it's busy (came here on a Thursday night), it will be difficult to find a place to sit. This bar is popular for a reason though. Since it's so small, you'll find it much easier to talk to the people around you. The decor throughout the place is amusing to watch while having a drink. Would come back :)
author: Trang L.

description: I love this place! So much good art and heart! My favorite place on the Mission, reminds me the old artistic San Francisco
author: Eli Z.

description:
* Albondigas Plate - 3.5 STARS ($8.95): Enjoyed the meatball flavor (comes with about 4 small medium pieces) except that there were some odd textures thrown in. The side salad was refreshing and the dressing was tasty. The rice was a necessary complement to the beans and saucy meatballs. 

* Sangria - 3 STARS ($6): for a large cup, $5 for a regular cup. Available in carafes. Sweet and tasty and undeniably an amazing deal. Maybe I'm a heavy weight but it tasted more like sugar and juice than alcohol. 

* House wine - 1 STAR ($5): Perhaps the worst house wine I've ever had. Stick with the sangria :P

Affordable place to grab some comfort food but don't expect quality sangria or alcohol.
author: Jess C.

description:
An old and wacky spot in the Mission, serving tasty sangria and wonderfully homey cuban food. I had the meatballs, which are stupidly delicious. Of course, a big part of the draw is the decor. I see something new every time I'm there. 
I also love coming here because I take any chance I can get to patronize older Valencia street restaurants. If we keep visiting them, then they're less likely to go out of business and be taken over by yuppy places that serve a fleck of gold-crusted bread for $15.
author: Sasha W.

description:
Wow this place is weird. But that's the what draws you in. I've walked by it many times and thought what a strange little place until finally I decided to wonder in for a drink.

When you walk in it's like your in your crazy aunts kitchen and she has a hoarding problem. It's kind of cool to see all of the stuff on the walls but at the same time it's pretty creepy when you look closely. It reminded me a lot of the creations Sid from Toy Story would create. Also it smelled like dirty cats, but don't worry you get used to that after a few minutes... ew. 

I was honestly shocked to see there was a food menu. Just judging on the smell of the place I would never even consider ordering food here. Not to mention when looking around it is difficult to find a kitchen... and after reading through previous Yelp reviews it sounds like most of it is canned and microwaved. We sat in the back and had two glasses (more like goblets) of sangria. The sangria is definitely good and the portion size is good, but you can get good sangria at a lot of places. There was nothing incredibly special about it. I know they have some live music here on occasion which could be cool to check out, but I don't really see myself coming back.
author: Mandy A.

description:
First impression felt like walking in to someone's living room with lots of dolls/parts of dolls hanging off objects.. A sociopaths dinner party? 

Would recommend this for small groups looking to catch up or even a casual first date. Very quirky and eclectic set of decorations in a spot thats no more than 150 sq foot. Quiet enough to carry a conversation without raising your voice. Easy going Latin beats in the air and the décor sparks a lot of conversation.
author: Nat E.

description: Favourite bar in the city! The cosiest, most weird & wonderful bar with incredible kitsch decorating all the walls, I love going in & just staring at the amazing pictures & mad combinations of Barbie dolls, scary nuns, creepy babies, unicorns & Cupids are hanging from the ceiling this week! The owners are lovely people, the sangria is amazing & the food delicious. I bring everyone from out of town here & they always remember it from their visit & rave about it. Love it!
author: Roe M.

description:
The decor is weird af haha! Super quirky, random stuff just hung all over the ceiling and walls. You know that weird broken baby doll in Toy Story? Yeah, many of those in this place. 

It's extremely small here too so it can't fit many people. Probably not the best place to come here with a large group of people but you can get lucky with a table or two, like we did. The owner (?) was this sweet oldish lady who was accommodating to our large group and finding chairs for us. So nice!

We got sangria here and it was SO GOOD. I downed that too quickly. The food was also super delicious and the price was only like $10!

Overall, I gave this place a 4 star because the space was too small.
author: Vio C.

description: Was excited to try this place because of its charming interior and low-key crowd. Unfortunately, the food and service didn't live up to all the good reviews I saw online. Both of our meals were underseasoned and they took creative license on some classic dishes which left us disappointed. People seem to love the sangria but I thought it tasted too sweet, like boxed wine. Slow service and cash only!
author: Turner W.

description: I brought some friends from out of town to this amazingly quirky restaurant that is full of character. Radio Havana Social Club is pretty small and the first thing you notice once you open their nondescript door are all the crazy trinkets! The interior is as if a hoarder decided to get organized in a fanciful and cluttered way. The service is attentive and the sangria is good. The food itself isn't anything amazing to write home about, but it's truly the ambience that you're coming for. On some nights they have a live band playing music in the dining area. Anyway, bringing my friends here was the perfect way to introduce them to how fun eating out in SF can be. They were blown away by RHSC and can't wait for our next SF culinary adventure!
author: Josh S.

description: Very slow service and a messy restroom. Sangria was ok, could have been stronger. The funky decor is somewhat cool (a little too much) but the poster of Stalin made me uncomfortable and the augmented babies were weird as hell. Don't come here if you're claustrophobic.
author: Alpo P.

description:
At first glance, you might think Radio Habana Social Club is intimidating. To be fair, from the outside, it looks more like a crazy person's apartment than an actual restaurant. I don't think anyone would fault you for completely missing this gem in the Mission, but if you've got a somewhat adventurous spirit, I suggest you open that door on Valencia and let yourself escape to Cuba. You will not regret it.

Just to give this review a little context- Cuba is, in many ways, like a real-life time machine. Because of Cuba's history and the US embargo, Cuba is saturated with old cars and buildings, and has the same aesthetic it did in the 1950's. 

Much like Cuba itself, Radio Habana Social Club is kept at a balmy 75-80 degrees (F), and is adorned with colorful relics of the past;  It really conveys the feeling that you've stepped out of reality and into someplace special- possibly the island of Cuba. The artist (and owner) has taken items we would normally discard as 'junk', and turned them into evocative pieces of art. I've noticed a general trend of babies portrayed in interesting ways, exploration of anatomical forms, as well as some distinctly ironic pieces and tributes to historical figures and celebrities from the past. One of my favorite pieces is hanging on the right-hand wall when you're facing in from the door, and features an angry male doll with the bottom half replaced by an electric drill- to me this seems like a literal representation of the saying, "i'm going to drill that girl". Fascinating. 

You can (and should) easily spend hours here exploring the resident artwork, as well as the photo collections on the back wall that change every month. And to assist you in that task, I recommend you enjoy a large princess cup (copa de reina) of their fantastic sangria. It is delicious, refreshing, and cheap, without being cloyingly sweet. I'm no aficionado, but its the best I've had.

The food, on the other hand, is only ok. The plantains are standard, but the empanada and ropa vieja were both disappointing. The empanada felt stale, and the ropa vieja lacked flavor and seasoning. I don't mind though, because the food was reasonably cheap, and I was more than content enjoying my sangria and admiring the amazing atmosphere of this place.
author: Zameer A.

description: So much character here. Such a symbol of what the Mission really stands for. The owner of this place had pro-Bernie signs on the windows, and I walked in with pro-Hillary signs I had just picked up. She welcomed me and we exchanged different points of view. Not to mention they had great South American influenced plates and beers.
author: S. A. K.

description: We thought it was going to be more of a bar, since it was seen on a list of weirdest bars in SF. So we just had Sangria...which was good. Not sure that I'd go back to eat tho.
author: Annette P.

description: Fun and eclectic little spot. Small place but very quaint. I had the albóndigas which came with rice and beans and small side salad. All tasty. The flan for dessert was also delish.
author: Gaby T.

description: It is all about the ambiance. Take a friend or 2 and enjoy a nice conversation over a sangria. Since I moved to SF last year, I was hoping to find a place similar to the ones that populate Barcelona, Buenos Aires, Paris or any other city with a cultural flair. Rumba Café in Washington DC is the only reference in the US that I know of. I am glad I found this place as it will be my place to go from now on.
author: Peti S.

description: It's a small place with funky decoration and delicious, ample portions of food. The staff are gentle, friendly folk. Honestly, I think we were lucky to get a table though we did get there around 8:30pm on a Monday night. For 3 entrees and 1 side plate plus 2 glasses of sangria, $50 incl/tax.
author: Frank L.

description:
For someone who is already confused by the busy streets of SF, this little hole-in-the-wall is not the place to be relax and have a dinner date with your other half. The decor in itself is just a little bit of everything from everywhere, and the word "eclectic" is a nice way to put it. The restaurant is small, almost suffocating. I think using the words "social club" is definitely pushing it.The food was sub-par... when I think of Cuban food I think of passion-filled food with lots of MOJO! And yet I feel that the seasoning fell short. The patrons definitely meant well in regards to the menu and gave the best service they could given the small space. 

Overall, Radio Habana has room for improvement. Had they had better food (or a well-built kitchen), a bigger place, A LOT less decor, and actual entertainment I would make an effort to come back.
author: Gaile G.

description: Ropa vieja was delicious! As was the picadillo. Ambiance was phenomenal; always had something interesting to look at. Very small, cozy place. Definitely be back.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Delicious Cuban Tapas Food. Small, cute restaurant with a gypsy table mish mash and alternative art hanging from the ceilings and in every nook and granny. Loved the atmosphere! My friend and I also luckily got there right when they opened there doors around 7. By the time we left there was a crowd of people waiting for tables. Small, intimate tables mean waiting for yummy food on most other occasions, so get there early. 

From what I could tell, it was an older husband and wife running the place with a tiny kitchen off to the side. 

My one recommendation, you should feel comfortable with taking service into your own hands here. 

Once my friend and I sat down we weren't really checked on again and had to switch a dish out for something else because there was a miscommunication with the dish ordered and it's meat vs. chicken availability. Which wasn't a problem, once we were able to get the cook/waiter's attention. So just don't expect to be pampered with service. 

I got up later to get my friend and I water and also to grab the check from the sweet women behind the small bar. 

I myself, don't mind taking things into my own hands. It was a very relaxed and pleasant dining experience otherwise. 

I just think it can be jarring to go in without those expectations.
author: Goth Kitty Jen J.

description: Simply put...THERE IS NO KITCHEN. ALL of their food comes out of a microwave. The ropa vieja is canned meat and the albondigas are frozen meatballs. NEVER COMING BACK.
author: Amie T.

description: Great little spot on Valencia great service best sangria I have ever had I had the chicken breast with lentils yummmmm and my boyfriend had the "tops vieja" super good! And again the sangria is to die for!
author: Jackie R.

description:
Went to this place last night. It was my third of fourth time there -- my first time having dinner there, though.

So, as you can tell by the other reviews, this place has some of the strangest, funniest, insane decorations you can imagine. It's collection of multimedia collage crafting with toys, tchotchkes, and other memorabilia into mobiles, sculptures, and mounted wall hangings is . . . conversation provoking to say the least. 

The proprietors are great, super nice. It's a low-key feel with more unique attributes than I could possibly name. 

The food was fine. Cuban, decent, reasonably priced, nothing special. The drinks, too, were fine, standard, but nothing special. But the vibe, the music, the memorabilia and oddness make this a great place to bring out-of-towners who you want to confuse (perhaps after blowing their minds with the Pirate Supply Store or Paxton Gate), a casual 1st date (plenty of stuff to talk about other than the weather), or anyone else. It's a strange place, but very comfortable and fun.
author: Dustin B.

description: Quirky, kitsch and a wonderland of junk made into art. Machine gun ken with his jungle Jane Barbie bitches adorn the wall. Photo Frank Zappa sitting on the loo. Get the Sangria. Fun stop in the mission
author: Jessabelle R.

description:
Someone erased my review.

My college buddy is Cuban; and we have had many a good Cubano meals.


The food here is mediocre at best; I would not return here. 

The other place in the Mission called El Fruiti...  serves Puerto Rican and Cuban. It's a bit better.

There is a better place in San Jose, see my reviews, it's on Almaden.

Customer service: fine.

Decor: Kitsch on the walls.
author: Bert K.

description:
This is a small place with a simple menu. So if you poke your head in and it is full, keep walking down Valencia.

But if you want to take a closer examination of all the "stuff" on the wall and off the ceiling, squeeze in and order a goblet of delicious sangria.

It is really ran by a couple of older ladies that will make sure they take care of you, but they do run out of food since their kitchen is only 6'x8'. They ran of rice and bean once, but they filled up my goblet which gets no complain from me.

Food are generally less than $10 per plate, your usual Cuban affair, all fresh and just like eating at my Cuban friend's house. Flan is a must.

Drop in and enjoyed a fun relax night in Habana!
author: Alice C.

description: Great vibe. Artsy interior. Authentic food. Great atmosphere. (And I'm Cuban by-the-way). Love it and would recommend.
author: Alexander V.

description: This is such a little gem of a restaurant. The decor is fun, quirky and thought provoking. The food is reliable cuban tapas that is made fresh and with good ingredients. The music is my favorite part.......... lots of good latin jazz. And I mean good. If you want a place that is as unique as San Francisco, this is the place.
author: Ronald B.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF! Definitely requires a sense of humor to enjoy the quirky, irreverent decor; I personally love it. The vegetarian plate is usually awesome, featuring a samosa-type dumpling, beans and rice, plantains, and salad. However, one night, they were out of samosas, and served lukewarm veggie-tater-tots instead... not so great. The sangria is sweet but potent. It's very small inside; perfect for a date with someone with a sense of adventure.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
"There's a large ear taped to the wall. It's part of a Van Gogh collage. A black and white photo cutout of his face has white gauze wrapped around the head. Red blood seeps through the bandage. By itself, this collage would be remarkable enough. Here at Radio Habana Social Club, this is one among hundreds of visual feasts awaiting your consumption. This tiny nightclub can barely fit ten, maybe twenty people. Yet the art cornucopia feels infinite."

I was inspired by Radio Habana to write the above introduction for my book, "iT felt Like A kiss", about art in the Mission district. I also held my book release party at Radio Habana with the help of the owners, Leila and Victor.

Victor is an artist and has collected all the art pieces in the restaurant/bar over the span of several years. Leila serves the drinks; Victor, her husband, prepares the food. Leila's sangria is one of the best you will find in the Mission and Victor makes samosas that rival those in Indian restaurants. They also serve beer, wine, empanadas and a variety of other food. On some weekends, they host live music on Sundays.

Radio Habana Social Club is a wonderful place for those with a taste for the esoteric in both art and ambience.
author: Leena P.

description:
A mom and pop with a latin flavor. The place is photographers dream with tiny little details to discover on the walls each time you visit. 

I tried the vegetarian plate and the ropa vieja. Both delicious and reasonably priced. The sangria deserves its fame, not too sweet, with a sneak up on you kick that makes you a mellow fellow even after only one. But you can have more at $5 to $6 a glass. 

The place gets extra credit for Victor the owner with his wife Leyla and Alejandro behind the bar. They made my visits that much more memorable.
author: MARCO S.

description: Disclaimer: I didn't have anything to eat. But the sangria was quite good, the owner was very nice, and the room is very cool. Key word: 'room'. This place is tiny. Maybe 3 4-tops and a bar with 3 seats. Floor to ceiling accreted decorations. The kind of atmosphere you can't quickly buy from a decorator. A nice hole in the wall. Only downside is that if you're a tall person (like me) your knees will start to hurt after cramming into the tiny chairs for an hour or two.
author: Nick S.

description:
Four of us ate there last Saturday night. I was surprised how small the place was - the name somehow lead me to believe it was a big social, dancing kind of a place but the food was epic and service very fast and friendly! I chicken enchilada - outstanding!! One friend had the ropa vieja and it was also very good.

There are interesting and odd items all of the walls which made it fun to look around. They are reminiscent of a santaria place I visited in Cuba. I would definitely recommend this place but not for a really big group.
author: Eileen O.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF, along with Specs and a few others on a short list.  Long live Victor, the cool soft spoken owner.
author: Andrew S.

description: A step back in time. You can stop in for a beer and chat with old-timers. One of the last remnants of what the Mission used to be. It's also a refuge on Saturday nights when Valencia gets inundated with Marina trash and obnoxious B&Ts.
author: Tracey W.

description:
Hoarding.

Walls are filled with art, photos, quotes and assorted random decor. Being such a small space it felt like we were in the home of a hoarder.

Not my design preference but to each there own. Especially when the food and drinks are this good.

We shared a mix of empanadas, tamales, potatoes and sangria. Each perfectly portioned and full of flavor. Food left me buzzing. Drink left me buzzed.

Two ladies working were charming and welcoming. You could tell they loved what they were doing and loved having people to share it with.

Cash only but you don't need too much. Very reasonably priced. Plus you get to say you dined in close quarters with 15 of your newest friends.

Bet you'll hoard the last bite.
author: Jason B.

description:
Radio Habana Social Club is my favorite stop for dinner,
good wine and beer, and the sangria is the best I've ever had. Not to speak about the wonderful people who own this place, Victor and Leila. Victor is the house artist and chef...really great chef...he creates gourmet food from a tiny kitchen...unbelievably good. His artwork is very powerful, and adorns the whole place, ceiling to floor.
You'll love Leila too..what a woman!
But what really makes this place my favorite is the overall ambiance...such a tiny place, with such a big and wonderful personality.
Go!!!
author: Johnny H.

description:
Not entirely sure what makes this place a "Social Club," but hey - it's a cool spot nonetheless.

Remember the contraption that ol' Pee Wee used to make breakfast on the quest to find his sweet bicycle? Well, imagine that sort of device, along with every nic-nac from every swap meet you've ever attended in your entire life, all adorned to the interior walls of a 20x20 foot room, and you've got Radio Habana.

Everything from Matchbox cars to a John Lennon action figure with a gun next to his head rests on the walls inside this place, which clearly evokes all kinds of different reactions. Not sure what to think about the Lennon display, but the coo-coo-clock with a hand drill sticking out is pretty great.

They have a really small bar, and I'm willing to bet 25 people could comfortably fit inside this space before it becomes asses to elbows. It's one of those places I'd walked by many times, but never stopped in. I have a feeling that happens a lot with these guys, so if you're looking for something different in the Mission, skip the fancy spots and get weird at Radio Habana.
author: Ruggy J.

description: When I want delicious food, chill crowd and unique atmosphere, I always find myself at Habana.  The staff is always so friendly and relaxed.  I love the live music. This gem in the Mission is not to be missed.
author: MaryAnn P.

description: Had delicious beef Chilean empanadas and a side of maduros. The place is cozy. The sangria was good but not the best I ever had. Service was great and friendly. Not sure about the decor. Good place to experience once. It's different and unique.
author: Shelly P.

description: Wanted to come to this place for a long time, and we finally did!!!! It provides an amazing atmosphere:) The place looks small from outside, but it can hold quite many ppl. People both workers and customers were so friendly and definitely coming back. We tried the special of the day which was something called Tofu Curry and it was delicious. We will try other dishes on the menu soon:)
author: Maitai N.

description:
Had a great date here! My fiancé and I were looking for a new local spot in the Mission to have some dinner and drinks and this did the trick.

This place is quite small but cozy with lots of music and conversation.  As a vegetarian, I marked off one star because there was only one entree and one appetizer option, but I was quite pleased with the food. 

This is a no rush spot, so we ended up staying to have another sangria plus espresso at the end of the night. With the massive amount of art on the walls, the conversation never got dull. 

A great spot to check out with an unpretentious subculture feeling. I will be back.
author: Lucille C.

description: Poor service and very average food. Trust me, I love weird places and this is definitely one of those...the interior is decorated with creepy amputated dolls and photos of Frankenstein themed creatures. While, I appreciate the creativity here, the tablecloth was filthy - unwashed and spilled over food from previous party. The lady serving us wouldn't even smile. This is my second time here and the service and food seems to have down the  drain. Overall, very disappointed.
author: Ram A.

description: There is something so special about this place. I just love it.  Its super duper tiny.   Theres always beautiful live music too!  Service is always great, food is decent, and the prices are very reasonable!  You will be fascinated with everything on the walls.
author: Coraly S.

description: Amazing space and the staff was great. Now the food itself was average at best. My cuban parents taught me to cook better & I'm no chef.
author: J M.

description:
I don't even know where to start with this place.

My friend had been wanting to come here for a while so we finally were able to catch it while it was open.  The decor is interesting.  I wonder if they ever dust.  It seems like it would be a lot of work to dust each and every mutilated baby, but back to the review.

The place is tiny.  Very, very tiny.  And hot.  Why on Earth is it so hot in there?  And its so tiny that apparently they only reheat food they purchased elsewhere because they are not whipping up gourmet meals in that kitchen.  I didn't order anything, but my friend got a mocha.  When he finally got the attention of the woman working at the bar she acted like he was inconveniencing her.  The way she leaned over and placed her hand on her temples, it was like my friend was asking her to solve world hunger.  

He paid $3.75 for some Ghiradelli mix that you can pick up at Safeway.  It was served scalding hot.  By the time he gets his drink my friend is in a hurry to get out of the restaurant before the waitress looks at us and sighs again.  But he can't hurry because the drink is too hot.  

We witnessed the waitress be really nice to someone who spoke Spanish to her, so maybe not speaking English is the key, I don't know.  I won't be going back to figure out.  So I feel like this would be a good place to go if your own microwave breaks and you can't heat up your own food, or if Safeway is out of cocoa.
author: Marie B.

description: Honestly very disappointing. Bad food, bad service, the lady working wouldn't even talk to us. Also wouldn't take $100 on a $78 bill, and it was cash only.
author: Captain Muffin D.

description:
This an art gallery/salon where people talk, drink and eat. Like the Paris salons of the 1890's this is a place where creative people come together amid an ever-changing array of conceptual art and a tribute wall to the creative spirit of the neighborhood. Victor is a Cuban artist who has created a social club for artists and intellectuals to hang out and conspire new art projects.  Great drinks and food for thought and to consume.
Hipsters and food snobs stay away!
author: Gregory L.

description: Who doesn't love this place?  The people are so nice, the food is solid, and the sangria is delish.  I love coming here with a few friends before or after a show.  Not ideal if there are more than four of you, though, as the quarters are tight.
author: Shasta S.

description:
Okay, the decor alone is enough to score this place a 4 star review.  I love all the crazy stuff hanging from the walls and ceilings - mug shots from cuba, a stuffed Pee Wee Herman doll with a knife in it, etc.

Stopped in with a buddy for some sangria.  It was wet, red and full of alcohol.  That's good.
author: Ivan L.

description: This little, tiny place is pretty cool. The art on the walls are out of this world and bizarre. The service is friendly but the place is super tiny. Two to four people max if you wanna have a good time. Their sangrias are pretty good and the food is just okay. Don't expect to get gourmet food as they don't really have a kitchen; this place is more about the experience.
author: Moy V.

description:
This place is a total hoot. Just walking by, you will know what I'm talking about. Walk in and you will be greeted by friendly staff who will escort you to a table if you plan on ordering food. You will not be quite sure what you've walked into, however. Is it a bar? A cafe? A living room? The art pieces that decorate the walls are incredible; a lot of Cuban art but also pop culture pieces. There is always something to look at an analyze. My favorite is the crutch/gun piece over the back table for 3. 

I am not a rice pudding fan but happened to order it last night and loved it! It was simple and delicious; how it's supposed to be. My friend had the chocolate devil pudding, equally as delicious. They have a lovely little wine/beer menu and a wide array of teas/coffee drinks for a chilly eve.

This is a great place to take a date who likes culture, to practice your espanol, or perhaps get lost with a book in the Mission and where no one else can find you. You can remain pretty anonymous in this haven of awesomeness.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Food wasn't really cuban as I expected, however it was really good. Very simple, naught to crazy food, and good sangria.

I gave four stars mostly because of the cool crazy looking place (really small) and the old couple who seemed to be running the place.

I liked it
author: Gerardo C.

description:
You have to love a place that has a rifle/crutch (or is it a crutch/rifle?) hanging on the wall.  That is equal opportunity warfare, my friends.  Actually, they have EVERYTHING hanging on the walls.   Bloody ears?  Check.  Reptile skull with an hourglass figure?  Check.  Antique photo of some lady with Princess Leia bun-hair?  Check.  (Don't worry -- I won't list the full decor inventory in this review, but know that it transcends art and politics and groovy.)

This place is about the size of my bedroom, and it's the perfect place to plan an uprising or just drink big glasses of sangria and pretend you're an ex-pat in a tropical land.  It's cozy and political and yummy at the same time.  The folks that run it are super friendly and distressed about old reviews that mention the unpleasant waitress that no longer works there.

(Bummer that the veggie selections are not actually Cuban, but yay for the rice and beans!  Delicioso!  Oh -- and it's cash only.)

Check it out, and help them bump up the positive reviews.  
Oye -- do your part for the revolucion.
author: Andi T.

description: I love this place. Very relaxed place to stop for a bit. Good  food and good sangria!
author: Aaron P.

description:
This is a kooky little place full of crazy junk that's run by a cute elderly couple. The food is decent but a bit pricey for what you get.

You can hang out at the tables and drink but you only get table service if you order food.
author: Manny F.

description: Amazing; the food, ambiance, service, and music. I had the Chicken Tamal plate and my friend had the Vegetarian plate. Both were excellently crafted and presented. My tamale was one of the best I've had. We had front row seats for an amazing 3 piece band who I really wish I'd found out the name of (night of August 27). Yes, it's tiny, but it honestly feels like you've stepped out of the city for a second, into a different place.
author: Flacita G.

description:
Freaky wierd twisted mind decor. The concept is unique but its just to psycho for my taste. 

MAJOR THUMBS DOWN to the chicken empanada. Tasted like a microwaed frozen burrito. That just could not be authentic. 

Good sangria & salad however I don't desire to go back.
author: E. Y. G.

description:
don't get locked in here at night when it's thunderstorming outside.

i mean, i didn't, but it would be scary.

the sangria was good, the jambalaya was not bad and so was the tamale. looking around while eating is by far the most fun.
author: Ameer N.

description: This place was amazing.  The art on the walls made for a wonderful atmosphere and, as I was on a date, also for a great ice breaker.  The server was hilarious -- dancing to and fro throughout the restaurant.  The food was delicious, the sangria was amazing, and it was a wonderful experience.  The price wasn't even so bad!  The only reason I'm not giving this place 5 stars is that the rice and salad that comes with the main dish was only so-so.  Everything else was fantastic and I will definitely be returning.
author: Ryan S.

description: Food was horrible. I can hear them pealing open the can. Sangria that was so much raved about..so, so...
author: Genie H.

description: A rare gem that is tried and true, this place has fantastic sangria and service with a smile. The place is family run and the menu always changes. The food is fresh, the music is lively and the art! Oh the art! It's hard to describe how amazing the art is. Imagine a pickle with Barbie doll legs with the Lone Ranger Riding it.  The place is super tiny, but if you can get a table do it. Have some sangria, delicious central American food, mingle with the primarily international crowd and enjoy.
author: Audra S.

description:
Very very very tripping place. They serve some food and have really good sangria. The decorations are very... erm... creative and... unique! I will definitely visit this place on Day of the Dead or around Halloween. 

I didn't realize Arnold Schwartzenegger's head was that big. ;)
author: Katie M.

description:
i've passed by this place so many times and loved the crazy decor inside but never got a chance to stop and eat. finally today, it was open for brunch! YES, opened where there's still sunlight! 

the menu for brunch is different from the dinner menu though. much smaller and pricey... i felt. we had the chicken tamal. the banana leaf wrapped tamale was plated with a side of black bean topped with slices of onion. yum. however, $8.50. 

the serve was super friendly and quick. my classmates and i sat at the bar which was nice and chat a bit with Maria [our server - who's a former printer]. 

it definitely a nice place to hang out, get a few drinks, and a lite fare. i can't wait to go back for dinner.
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
I found out about this place when a musician friend of mine told me they host a Rumba on every other Sunday.    What is a rumba?  its a cuban hoe-down!   Afrocuban percussive music and singing by mostly locals, trying to work it out!   I love cultural events that are free, and I love rhythmic music, so I'm there.

I haven't really eaten there except for the snacks they've kindly put out for the musicians... but I had Sangria there and it was lovely.

If you like to roam the Mission, looking for little cultural gems, this place might hit the spot for you, especially on those Rumba Sundays.    And if you're not there for the music,  there's plenty of stuff on the walls to keep you amused for a while.
author: Afshin M.

description:
Apparently I'm a fan of the kitsch and didn't even know it- cause I really liked this place.  

We sat at a table near a full sized silver crutch/gun, just one item among lots of other random stuff glued to the walls, hanging from the ceiling, and imprinted on the floors.  Fascinating, and I probably could've spent hours ignoring my dining partner and reveling at the surrounds.  

And maybe I'm a little OCD, but I was really impressed that even with all the crap glued to the walls, there wasn't a speck of dust anywhere!

Good coffee and chai tea lattes, and sangria seemed to be the drink of choice.  Interesting crowd, very nice owner.
author: Joanne G.

description:
"Hey Farva, what's the name of that restaurant you like with all the goofy shit on the walls?"

"You mean Radio Habana?" 

"Oooooooooooh!"
author: Laura B.

description:
Walking down Valencia, I've passed by this little restaurant plenty of times.

I finally had the excuse to go when a few friends were visiting from out of town. I though the cozy atmosphere and eccentric decor would make for a unique experience.

We ordered the samosa plate, which came with I believe one vegetarian samosa, some rice, and a itty bit of salad. I was dissatisfied with the plate, the portions were dismal for the price of $12.

I dug the sangria though. Even though there wasn't much fruit in it (I like my sangria to be loaded with fruit), it was nicely chilled and had a really sweet taste.
author: Valerie L.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, we wanted to try some Cuban food.  Of course we fired up Yelp and were presented with a number of listings.  The name of this establishment caught my attention, I mean, The Radio Habana Social Club?.  My mind was filled with all sorts of images of what this place would be like.

We arrived to find the establishment tucked between other businesses; this place was incredibly unique and incredibly tiny.  Finding out later that it is better known for its wine selection than the food made perfect sense.  They have a Sangria that is fantastic and a limited menu (and not necessarily Cuban).  We had a blast taking in the decor (there is a subtle but bizarre sexual overtone that is not offensive, but you may want to get a babysitter for your night out).

I really enjoyed the food, our waitress/hostess was one of the owners and we had good conversations between servings.  This is a funko-wonderful establishment and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a trip off the beaten path.
author: John P.

description:
You will walk into Radio Habana gawking at the walls and you will leave Radio Habana still gawking at the walls.  Every inch of this place is adorned with the most kitschy things I've ever seen.  A crutch-turned-machine gun, photos of Cuban granny boobies, fishnet stockinged mannequin legs hanging out of the wall, and voodooed Barbie dolls, to name a few.

The menu is very limited.  I was hoping to have one of those classic Cuban dishes like ropa vieja, but they don't offer that here.  They actually don't serve anything very Cuban.  They have empanadas, tamals, samosas, and albondigas.  While the prices are pretty cheap, the portions are small.  What was most disconcerting to me was that the food isn't even cooked here.  There is no kitchen!  The food is warmed by microwaves, ovens, and food warmers.

Albeit I wouldn't come back for the food, I would definitely be back for the chill environment, fun ambiance, great salsa music and dangerously good sangria.  This is the perfect place to hang out with a friend or two.  Or even to pick up on a girl, because on that particular Friday night I ventured to Radio Habana, EVERY. SINGLE. patron here was a girl.  Single guys and single female-loving ladies, you've just discovered your new Friday hangout.
author: Diane L.

description: A warm oasis of kitschy Cuban comfort in a ocean of hipsterville. We stumbled upon Radio Habana on a cold Saturday night in the Mission, after being brushed away by a string of weiry hostesses we where welcomed in Cuban fashion by a quirky dreamy 'beinvenido'. All of this being said, a restaurant can not survive on atmosphere alone, so I am happy to say that the food has all the flavor, soul and simplicity that I remember from the island in the Caribbean.
author: Camilla B.

description: I always try to pass by Radio Habana when I'm on Valencia. Great art, awesome food, good people. A truly unique place!
author: G. G. H.

description: This restaurant is a real treat, though more or less so depending on how crowed the *tiny* space is and who is playing music. The food and drink is good and priced right. If you do have to wait and you're inside, you have PLENTY to look at all over the walls.
author: Jason A.

description:
I initially wasn't going to review this place because it's been about 2 months since I came here, and I was conflicted about how many stars I should give this place. However, I had to write a review so people will know what to expect. At first, I wanted to give this place 2 stars because despite the decor and food, I had a good time. There was a local guitarist and singer that came by this tiny, hole in the wall place to perform, and I was really entertained. But I can't say that I'll be back. I'll just watch them perform somewhere else. The decor is enough to keep me away despite the good service and good time that I had here. Therefore, this place gets 1 star for 'eek! methinks not'.

DECOR: The decor here gives me that sick-to-the-stomach, nervous, uncomfortable feeling (that feeling you get, when something that you're absolutely dreading starts approaching). My friend said that this means that it's 'art', but can everything that evokes strong emotion out of you be considered art? Honestly, the 'art' sucks. If you've seen Toy Story, it's like Sid grew up decided to open up a tiny place to eat and glued all his distorted dolls on the walls (Oh, and he's all grown up so he has some 'mature' messed-up dolls). You have to see for yourself, (look at the attached pictures) but the wall is COMPLETELY covered with straight up weird stuff. I never say that things are 'weird' because I really believe that things that are different gives a place character. I actually enjoy places that are unique. But if 'unique-ness' was a scale, this place wouldn't even be on it. It's just creepy and pervy. The person who came up with this has a pretty sick and twisted mind.

SERVICE: I think our servers were the owners. I felt at home here. By the end of the night, this place was really crowded/cramped, and everyone was talking to everyone even though they came with different groups of people. This was pretty fun.

FOOD: I shared a tamale with a friend. I don't know why people love the food so much; it was okay and overpriced. Haven't they had more delicious ones in socal? Even though it edible I only had like one or two bites. I couldn't eat because i felt so uncomfortable from the decor. I felt like a zillion eyes (dolls) were looking at me, and actually kind of wanted to throw up. In addition, the kitchen is exposed to the customers. It is big enough for you to walk in and turn around 360 degrees; it's that tiny. I was able to see them make the food. It looked pretty unsanitary. I was not happy. I don't know if all restaurants are like this (because I usually can't see), but I didn't appreciate how the 'cook' who's also the waiter touched the lettuce with his bare, unwashed hands. 

DRINKS: Our party got pitchers of Sangria. It was pretty deliciously authentic. If I could just give a rating for the drinks without thinking about the decor, I'd give it 4 stars!

So in conclusion, unless I have a strong desire to feel nauseous and throw-up and have nightmares, I'll probably never ever be back.
author: Eunice R.

description: This place is whack-a-doodle.  But what a great spot to grab a pitcher of sangria and pretend like you're a tourist in a Spanish speaking country.
author: Laurence W.

description: Love this place. Service is super friendly, decor is awesome and the empanadas are  great too.
author: Zachary S.

description: This place doesn't even deserve one star in my opinion. All of the decorations are just a distraction. This place has no kitchen. They serve you pre made food and microwave it. I will never step foot in here again and I will warn others to AVOID THIS PLACE!!
author: christina d.

description:
Where did they GET all that crap?  That is the most stuff crammed into the  smallest space I have ever seen.  There is always something to look at though, so it would be good to come here if you are ADD, or if your dining companion is really boring to talk to.  Fortunately mine was not. 

The food was decent but the sangria was KICK ASS.
Seriously, the best sangria I have ever tasted.
author: Starla D.

description:
If I lived many lifetimes....
And kept all of the coolest shit I've ever come across in a box...
And that box exploded...
And all my cool shit stuck to the walls and ceiling...
And I learned how to make the best sangria...

...It would still be nowhere near as awesome as Radio Habana effortlessly is.

I can't speak highly enough of this place--and I haven't even had the food!  What I have had is Radio Habana Social Club and it's delicious sangria as the highlight of many a night out in the Mission.  And you know what?  I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Eric E.

description:
Think about every possible thing your eccentric packrat aunt from South America would have collected from childhood to six feet under: mutilated barbies, Dali prints, concert tickets, signed Santana photos, scores of music, Van Gogh's ear, and mount everything onto every inch of wall space in a small room. That's the decor in this place. Add five cozy tables and voila, the RHSC. We were greeted by a smiling gap toothed lady (the aunt/owner no doubt) and invited to sit. Good thing there were only four things on the menu so we had time to marvel at the walls.

From the kitchen came a long place of Salvadoran chicken (much like a tamale but wrapped instead in a banana leaf) pyramidal basmati rice,  organic greens, black beans and two goblets full of watery, sweetish sangria. Definitely worth a revisit.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
When I used to live in the Mission, back when it was a little more Missiony, my friend Charlie and I used to walk by Radio Habana and laugh about how it was never open.

Without fail, any time of day, the place was never open.  Then we got a car and noticed, from time to time, driving by, it would be open. Not only open,     but packed!

We knew we had to go in, but just weren't sure when it happened.

One night the stars finally aligned. We had some beer and coffee and good conversation with a slew of characters.

These days I don't make it back to the old 'hood very often, but when I do --and if it's open-- the Social Club is on my list.

It feels like you're in Manu Chao's living room.
author: Jason R.

description:
Hey Kimby T and I had fun here. We only had the sangria which was pretty tasty. Love the decor and the person working that night was friendly. 

I promised Kimby T. that we would come back and have their food. 
I will report back!!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
I just had my birthday and a handsome friend offered to take me anywhere in the city. Mind you there was no time to make a reservation, I had no desire to change out of my jeans and hoodie, and I wanted to go someplace interesting. So I picked Radio. It is now the scene of my favorite birthday moment: The bartender/server/social diva, Shawn, had her friend over at Garcon (yum) get me a desert. They lit a candle, turned off all the lights, and everyone (all 15 patrons that could fit in there) sang the worst rendition of happy birthday I ever heard. It was the perfect birthday dinner.

PS- I am vegetarian and love the food there, the sangria is authentic, and the owner's wife creates all the art and painstakingly makes it look random. There's actually method to the madness.
author: Regina S.

description: Everytime I'm in the neighborhood, I pass by and peer through the window and look longingly inside, wishing it was open. I finally got lucky and wandered by when it was open, and let me tell you, this place is way better inside than just peeking inside the window from the street. I had the sangria and it was delish. Make sure you play I Spy there, because it's the best place to play that game. :)
author: Sabina And Pete V.

description:
Hm.

I'm surprised but not too surprised by the general high-rating of this place. During my first visit I thought the drunken staff were utterly hilarious and almost themselves part of the wacky decor! On my second go-around our server was definitely nothing of the sort. I have some food restrictions and she was not only unable, but unwilling to check the ingredients. Apparently, they do not make any of their own food. They buy it elsewhere and then just heat it up!

The only thing really going for this place, to me anyway, is the little man in the hat who serves up sangria. And also all the funky shit on the walls. That stuff really does make me smile.
author: Marie D.

description:
I have never been to Cuba,,, or any South American country... or any Caribbean island either, but you have on my good authority that this is exactly what it is like... well except for the poverty, the totalitarianism, and the oppression.

But you don't need to suffer all that just to get a taste. The RHSC has good, simple, well-priced food in a small (tiny) venue - so homely, you could be in someone's kitchen. 

So I imagine it is in Cuba - you feel like you are in some subversive Cuban cafe, drinking large glasses of sangria, speaking in hushed tones, and passing notes to the waitress. And, as with all fine repressive regimes, the people find solace in art and religion, making a message out of whatever they can find, completely covering the walls with skulls and posters and artifacts and black magic.

Go here with a good conversationalist and speak of all the rights and wrongs of the world and plot how you will fix them.  If your conversation flags, you can poach a few plans from the other tables in the cozy dining room, or try to decipher the meanings of the subversive junk covering every inch of the walls.
author: Kingpin X.

description: 3.5. I am just crazy about the ambiance of this place. Customer service is first rate. 3.5 stars is due to the mediocrity of the hot chocolate & coffee. Despite that, I would go back to this place!
author: Paige J.

description: OK, so the food here is not haute cuisine but everything else about this place is outstanding.  Ambience?  Incredible.  Cute servers?  Definitely.  Yummy sangria?  Yep.  And you get a lot of bang for your buck.  One of my favorite places on earth, and such a hidden gem.
author: J Moses C.

description:
This place has such a great salon style compactedness of imagery and people that warms me. After I first saw it, I couldn't wait to come back with a friend. It was lively and food & sangria were good, but I couldn't help but be turned off by the rude, awful waitress (friday night). She wouldn't look at us unless we sought her attention and the way she was so blatant about it...bringing food & drinks first to people who arrived 1/2hr after us, it taking about 45 minutes after asking to get each drink, me begging for water 3 times and never getting it... I felt almost as if she didn't want us there. Most of everyone else who seemed like regulars were getting fine treatment.
Lady, I was nice to you - why'd you have to ruin it for me?
author: Steph K.

description:
Radio Habana Social Club is a hole-in-the-wall full of character.  And full of crap on the wall.  Take Applebees decor, add TGI Fridays, subtract commercialism and multiple by communist overtones and you have the decor.  My favorite item within the "junk on the wall" motif happened to be posted right next to my table: a magnify glass affixed to a tiny picture of a naked John Lennon and Yoko Ono.

This is a great place to grab some sangria with a friend.  Big groups should stay clear as there are only a few tiny tables in the cramped restaurant.  I also recommend that you come for the sangria and not the food.  The food wasn't bad, but the menu tiny.  Each dish involved a mound of rice, black beans, salad and something like an empanada or samosas.  The kitchen was smaller than that in my apartment and I heard the beeping of a microwave go off.

The food wasn't terribly exciting but the sangria and charm make this is a fun spot.  That and the stuff on the wall is excellent fodder for conversation.
author: Jamie Y.

description:
Wow, why is this a 4 star place?

We were seated a few feet from the kitchen and heard our dinner being microwaved. The food tasted like it had been cooked days earlier and was reheated. There was a hair in my empanada.

The restaurant is conveniently called "Radio Habana's Social Club," as the owner and sole chef were socializing with a table the entire time.

I'd probably go to the tapas place around the corner instead..
author: Evan M.

description:
The food is good.
The atmosphere and decor amazing.
The price is right.

 From tamales to meatballs, and black beans and rice the menu represents and ecclectic fusion of Southern Hemisphere food.

It's the price (everything under $10) and the wacky, fun decor that make it awesome.
author: Shayna N.

description:
Don't go to Radio Habana for a work function or with your devout grandmother. 

Do go with friends, lovers and/or  the ghost of Andre Breton.  Drink too much sangria and enjoy a banana-leaf-wrapped tamal.
author: Kiira M.

description:
It's like visiting your crazy aunt's home, the one who took a lot of acid and followed the Grateful Dead and became a lesbian and joined a hippie commune, and now putters around in sandals and a floppy straw hat tending the compost bin.  It's hard to tell guests from staff, hangers on, and extended family.  Everyone is wearing colorful peasant clothes and costume jewelry, in equal measure beautifully kind and completely forgetful and unhurried, and they're all leaning across the tiny room to chat with each other.  Average age is 50-60 on a weeknight but a few earth children too.  The decor is like every shrine to John Lennon, sexual pun art poster, paint-solidified clothing article, antique framed poster of leftist hero, and hanging plastic mannequin part you've ever seen, glued, stapled, and nailed like a barnacle colony to every available square inch of surface.

The food is pretty to look at but bland as a TV dinner, I guess that's the price of admission.  Surprisingly they have sangria and beer on tap, you would think it would be wheat grass or kambucha.   Open and crowded until midnight, very inexpensive.
author: Gil S.

description: Can't believe I had never gone in here before. Totally delightful. Chicken tamal plate delicious. Want to bring friends and come back soon
author: Debra C.

description:
My boyfriend and I went there for my birthday and it was just the two of us. We had been desperately in search for some authentic (or at least close to it) Cuban food since our recent trip to Miami. In our search we stumbled upon this little whole in the wall gem of San Francisco. 

Location: Walking up to the restaurant, we were at first deceived as its appearance from the outside seemed like that of a small convenience store struggling to attract customers as it was tucked ever so far away from the hustle and bustle of endless rows of restaurants a few blocks down. However, once we walked in, San Francisco, the Mission, and almost the entire state of California disappeared! Radio Habana Social Club whisked us away to Little Cuba (Miami) and good old Habana with its quirky, abstractly, zany, and creatively decorated walls.  A plethora of memorabilia dating back from the late 1920s (possibly older) all the way up to the present was like a blitz of art one would find in Dali's Figueres museum, even Van Gouh's ear was artfully arranged above dining tables!  And nevermind the tight quarters, this place almost commanded your attention to the walls as no corner, table, or plate was left untouched by the magic this place visually created.

Food: Unlike its atmosphere, a complicated and unimaginable compilation of old and new Habana-esque memorabilia, the menu was simple and to the point. It had 5-6 main dishes and possibly 3 appetizers, all of which were close if not original cuban recipes. It was a month or so ago since we were last there, so I the name of our dishes escape me at the moment. What I can tell you is that the actual meal was delicious. The recipes were simple, as they should be, and left us feeling contentedly full. 

Price: Excellent. It was perfectly reasonable for what we ordered.
Service: Hospitable and kind. In fact, my boyfriend (a native Cubano) over heard the cook (Husband) arguing with the waitress/ host (his wife) in Spanish (cuban style). For him and for me, this made us feel more and more as though we were taking part in something authentic, real, and totally untouched. And though they squabbled, their kindness to us and their hospitality did not falter.

Overall: If you want to allow not only your taste buds, but also your mind a little escape to Habana, this place is just for you. I will say this, be prepared to wait if you venture into this place on a weekend!
author: Michele H.

description:
'Dali-esque' is how i would describe Radio Habana. 

Also, you remember that mean kid next door in Toy Story? This is his room

Decapitated toys and sodomized dolls, thats what this place is all about.

Sangrias are cheap, the cuban food is yummy. Service is warm and friendly. 

The great thing is, if you're on a date you'll never run out of things to talk about because every piece of kooky art on the wall is a conversation starter.

George Orwell once wrote "One ought to be able to hold in one's head simultaneously the two facts that Dali is a good draughtsman and a disgusting human being."

I actually find it quite refreshing myself.
author: Tak H.

description:
Radio Habana caught my eye when I lived a block away . . . this little enigma of a space is packed to the gills with old timers and an otherwise completely random crowd, as well as doll heads, shotgun crutches, bird cages, portraits of dictators, and all manner of literary miscellany and city ephemera.  

For the longest time I'd walk by curiously, peering in what looked like a creepily deserted space.  Radio Habana does have some odd hours.  Finally one night I went in for a pitcher of their EXCELLENT sangria, and the secret world within was revealed.  

This was no ordinary night of drinking - literally the entire 'social club' seemed to know each other.  One table, conversing loudly, would attract the attention of the three other nearby tables at various points, who would randomly turn and interject their own rowdy commentary.  I suppose this is exactly how I'd dreamed/imagined it would be, but I never quite thought it'd come true.  This is one of those places that really feels like a trip down the rabbit hole - a quality establishment.
author: Natalie S.

description: OK place to get an ok drink but very tight space with a lot to look at!!! Crazy!
author: P G.

description: I am a huge fan.  They have two yummy vegetarian options, and delicious Sangria.  I love all the art on the walls, it is fantastic.  The pace is slow but you do not have to wait long for your food.  You should not come here if you are looking for massive plates, or if you want your server to hold your hand while you are eating.  They are very nice but they let you enjoy your meal at the pace you want, with the people you want--most likely, you will have to ask them for your check.  The servings are just right; you feel like you ate a meal but you are not over stuffed.  This is a good thing.
author: emilie p.

description: Great food and super fun music. The entrees are affordable and very tasty. I especially loved the decor on the walls. Their beer selection is small yet high in quality. This place is a 4-star spot, but beware of the line which forms quickly for dinner.
author: Lisa R.

description: All the people who gave four or five star ratings, did they actually eat here?  Admittedly, this place has character to spare, but the food was so mediocre.  Small portions with little flavor.  Good sangria, but still.  Restaurants should serve good food.  I wanted a meal, not a museum.
author: Devon R.

description:
This is a groovy little spot is a delight for the eyes, in a stimulating over-the-top, carefree, pack-rat kinda way. Tiffany L's description is spot on.  

A little later on, while waiting in line for the toilet, I noticed that a previously innocuous looking Barbie mounted on the wall, legs widely ajar, was actually enjoying [sexy-time] with a big red lobster outfitted with a human-baby's head ... !!!

The sangria by the carafe was also delicious and refreshing! Quirky & good for weeknight drinky-drinky or downtempo jollification. 5 Stars!
author: I. O.

description:
My favorite feature, for person, place or thing, is "clever".     Clever knocks my socks off, makes me giggle with glee, my heart pitter patter and my blood pressure raise in a good way. 

The hours for Radio Habana seem a little unpredictable  and I wouldn't have known about this place if my friend PD hadn't pointed it out.    In fact, the first couple of times I tried to go,  I was left peering into the window around the closed sign...

The decor is fascinating (disturbing for the weak of heart), the food is simple, but delicious and very well presented.   Sangria is fabulous and the service is weird but lovely.  

My fantasy is to have a Misfit Orphans Thanksgiving  feast here...
author: Maria C.

description:
This place is a gem! Tons of cool "surrealism" art plastering the walls.... goblets of delicious sangria and a short but sweet menu of home made/traditional/non traditional fare. 
The food is a mix of Indian-Cuban-El Salvadorian .... trippy but fantastic blend.  It'ss like mash-up house music... old shit you love mixed with new stuff your into... gets the blood flowing.
This place is VERY small though ... so go with the one person you want to be with that night :)
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Wow... am I the only honest reviewer?  We went on a Friday night at 9PM and it was relatively busy - it's a small place with seating for maybe 15-20.  Other than the friendly-ish service, there's nothing that values any more than 1-star here.

Here's the lowdown:
Sangria:  The only thing "special" about this house specialty is that it's basically flat and non-alcholic
Food:  We sat where we can see the kitchen - everything came out of a toaster or the microwave; nothing was fresh made and you could taste it.  I had the empanada (Lean Pockets are better!), and my friend had the tamal (just okay but the lady at the 24th st. BART does a better job)
Portions: Small - we weren't very hungy so it was fine, but if you have a healthy appetite you'll need two dishes.
Ambiance: If you like tropical, you'll feel at home: such a small place that the heat from the toaster over and microwave make it muggy and humid.  Even with the fans be prepared to strip down.
Decor: Kitchy.
Price: overpriced for the quality and quantity of food.  

Bottom line: if you are in the area and craving a little Latin American with a good ambiance and good alochol, go to the Velvet Cantina which is less than a block away at 23rd and Bartlett.   Way more bang for your buck and somewhere you'll actually want to go back to (read my review on that place for more info)
author: Simmi M.

description: Went here during the AGU conference in early December. Yelp for San Francisco restaurants was accurate once again. The ambience here is great. Its a hole in the wall with crazy amounts of decorations everywhere. At first we were the only people there and once we ordered our food one of two people in the restaurant went into a room that we had a clear view of and started prepping our meals. Its super cozy and funky. It seems like all the people who eat there are locals. We had sangria and we both decided to order the ropa vieja plus an order of fried plantains. I've had a lot of Cuban food before and this was actually almost like a healthier version. It seemed less heavy and greasy and seemed more fresh while still maintaining the typical zesty flavoring. The sangria was delicious and they gave us huge glasses. I'll have to admit I got a bit tipsy from that one glass. Overall the food was great and the ambience was cozy but lively. I definitely recommend it for any occasion but maybe not a business meeting.
author: Sonya C.

description:
I give this place five stars for atmosphere, though it somewhat depends what you are looking for. The food selection is very limited, which is why I give it a four as a restaurant overall.

This little hole in the wall epitomizes the adorably funky side of San Francisco.  All available surfaces covered with oddball, funny humorous art projects, more stuff hanging from the ceiling, crazy sculptures and photos, naughty Barbies, etc.  This place is not recommended for Neocons, prudes, or people without a sense of humor.

Radio Habana is a good place to go with 1-2 friends and get a drink--it's very small and has only maybe 5-6 little tables and a little bar serving salads, food and dessert (small selection.)  More importantly, they have beer on tap, sangria, and strong coffee,  which is all you really need, right? Service is very friendly.

Go here with a friend or two to relax and chat -- bring cash, they don't take credit.
author: John S.

description:
From the outside, the crazy walls seem to draw you in.  It gives you something to look at while you wait.

Food could be better but a cozy place to kill time with a 1-3 people. Their sangria was nothing to brag about and made me realize how good I've had it elsewhere.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this hole-in-the-wall eatery laden with friendly staff and art morphed from ordinary objects.  i enjoyed a couple of glasses of their sangria at $5/large glass; the food rivals the drink in economy, and the price is definitely right!  i had the albondigas which were saucy (meow!) and delicious!  Mesch had the empanada which was interesting and differed from my previous empanada experiences in that it was not dripping with grease.  i appreciated especially the perfect pyramids of rice from the kitchen.

one can really sit for hours in this tiny space and be entertained by the eclectic art, and lively music.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Great eclectic ambiance certainly not for the meek, type A personalities or those slumming from Pacific Heights but authentic in it's own right, populated with LatAm expats and wannabes. Must rank pretty low on the hipster radar (a good thing) except those that come looking for a sangria buzz.

Good food (very limited menu remember it has to come out of that tiny tiny kitchen reminiscent of Havana or one you'd find in a New York City studio apartment) had the meatballs and empanada both good 'n tasty and great sangria (they don't fill it with ice nor is it that syrupy Hawaiian punch you find in most places) all at reasonable prices and friendly proprietors to boot. Cheap and cheerful in the 'hood meant in the best sense.
author: Valerie R.

description:
I decided to go to Radio Habana Social Club based on the reviews I read here, but I have to say that I was a little disappointed by the food.

I can see how it can be a fun and cosy place to get a glass of sangria, but don't expect much for the food. There are basically four or five different plates (dinner plates with salad, rice and beans are $8.5, the exact same things but just with salad are called tapas and are $5.5).

Good thing: the waitress was super friendly. And at least, if you just argued with your BF, and don't talk to him at all, you have stuff to look at around to keep you busy.
author: Catherine L.

description: Radio Habana Social Club is one of my favorite places in the city. I've been going every 2nd and 4th Sunday to play Cuban Rumba. It's the only place in the city that showcases live Cuban drumming.
author: Geordie V.

description: I appreciate that Nish said the conversation was the real draw, since I was his conversation partner. Maybe he said that to be nice that is his style...  Anyways, back to the review. The food was okay, certainly edible but I have to say the portions were on the skimpy side. I left hungry, but my wallet was full since this place was cheap. The decor was amusing, very quirky and definitely Mission. The waitress was outgoing and talked to most of the patrons, which I found amusing and endearing.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This is a great place to play 'I spy'. Try to find Pee Wee Herman humping Minnie Mouse, or the shark with a skull head.

The kitchen is the size of a closet and the patrons at the bar are taking away in fast pased cuban-accented spanish.  The food smells awesome, and looks authentic - well the guy cooking it is certainly authentic so the food must be too, right?

Don't expect to be coddled, and don't think that you're special.  This is one of those special places that you're lucky to find, not a place that's they're lucky to find you.
author: Krissy M.

description:
Sangria, Toys, Sangria, Stuff on Wall, Sangria! This place is just too awesome. A person with ADD should definitely not go here because he/she would not be able to hold a conversation. The walls are plastered with odd semi-erotic items and dolls and newspaper clippings. the spot is way small so be ready to be crammed, but its totally worth it. for $6 a pitcher of yummy sangria this would have to be the spot that i would go to every evening. 

i will have to try the food next time - it looked delic.
author: Anita C.

description: Don't go expecting traditional Cuban.  Sangria is good. Go for atmosphere and specifically an environment conducive to hours of good conversation. The business owner is a delightful quirky, Amelia Bedelia type. She makes the place. The meatballs weren't quite legendary, but good enough to consume again. Rice and beans could use a little salt. Definitely an experience.
author: Andrew K.

description:
If you are a fan of sangria, you should try this place.  If you are a fan of wacky decor, you should try this place.  If you are a fan of long menus and/or extensive seating, you might want to move along now.

This is a great place for a small meal and a couple drinks in the Mission.  The menu is small, but tasty (though I dinged them a star since they didn't have the samosa I wanted), and the sangria is definitely something you should try before leaving this city.

The staff is quirky (in a good way), but then again, so is the ambiance.

I am pretty certain they are cash only, and just so you know, don't smoke on the stoop next door: they don't like it!
author: Shane L.

description:
What a place ! You HAVE to go there, is one of the Mission experiences.
It only has 4 or 5 dishes, only has Anchor Steam, but ... who cares!
Look at the pictures and you will start to understand. If you speak Spanish talk to the guy. What the hell! Talk to him anyway. Super-funny.
author: Javi V.

description:
Came here for a few drinks. Love love love this place!!! Cant stop looking at the walls, ceiling, everything in this little joint!
Sangrias, beers, then cake and hot chocolate (cheesecake was delish!).
Love the decor!!!!
author: Lina C.

description:
Food?  Get the plate of rice and beans.
Drink? Get a beer.
Enjoy the funky ambience, the Cuban-native SF transplant groups huddling in the back, the regulars, the kitsch and the art that is constantly changing and busting from the walls...
A truly unique place in the city.
author: amanda g.

description:
Happened upon this place after intending to go to Spork across the street but then deciding it was a little more than we wanted to spend.  We had dinner and sangria.  The food was suitable but not outstanding, but the décor and vibe made up for it.  

As for the food, my biggest beef was the lack of choices and the too small portion sizes.  In terms of main courses, you can choose between five or six "entrees" each of which come with a salad and rice/beans.  The problem is that none of the entrees are truly entrees.  I'm sorry but an empanada or a few smallish meatballs is not an entrée in my book.  The portions are too little to feed the truly hungry, but might be perfect if you don't like feeling absolutely stuffed after dinner.  That said, the food itself was tasty.  My meatballs were juicy and smothered in a tangy tomato sauce, part Italian part Latin.  The black beans were very flavorful.    

The décor and vibe did make up for the empty spot in my stomach.  The place is cozy and the walls are covered with plenty of conversation pieces.  Is that a lobster 69-ing a shark-mermaid hanging from the ceiling?  Yes, by golly, it is.
author: Jon B.

description: i don't care what anyone else says about the mission. i love it. i love all of it. the hipsters, gangsters, vagabonds, dives, little ice cream shops, amazing foodie restaurants, bars, and, of course, radio habana social club. i've been here with several friends on separate occasions and every time was a fun experience. even though it is a small place we danced around to the cuban music. we spent our time perusing the walls and all the quirky decorations. the details are worth taking your time. the food is always uber tasty! great memories here!!! will be coming here as long as they are open, which i hope is for a very long time.
author: Qui K.

description:
Baby, you get four points just for being surly. 

We arrived at 7:30, one half-hour past the scheduled (and conspicuously posted) opening time, only to find the front door locked. We were about to turn around and go elsewhere until a woman appeared suddenly in the dining area and started making faces at us. 

Her eyes got real big and she started shaking her head like a vagrant with Tourette's. Then she broke character and asked, "Whaddya want?" 

"To come in?" I no longer knew for sure. 

"Alright," she moaned and the door slowly opened. She peaked out and scanned the street like the bouncer at an opium den. "But now you gotta guard the door. You decide if someone's gonna come in or out."

"But I'm not big enough to be the body guard," I insisted.

"That's your problem," she said and retreated to the kitchen.

REVIEW: The food is alright and the drinks are palatable but the experience (the interiors, the service, and the adoring customers) are well worth the trip--or the wait to get in, which always occurs later on.
author: Michael P.

description:
