I'm particular in my loves...my grilled cheese must be made with white bread and american cheese, my tuna salad must NOT contain pickles, and - above all - my sangria must not be too sweet. Rule of thumb: if I can't down three glasses of it because it contains too much sugar, it's not for me.

WARNING: Bold statement ahead:

This is the best sangria I've had in the city. No lie. I had, um, three (plus one) glasses and while I did walk away a bit tipsy, it was worth every minute of the hangover the next day. The maestros at this small, kitschy restaurant somehow created a concoction that blends the perfect amount of sugar, fruit, and alcohol that renders it phenomenally drinkable. Maybe too-much so...my friend had to convince me NOT to have another glass. Thanks, buddy.

The menu is very sparse, but tasty. We ate the vegetarian samosas (yum) and quiche; they come with rice and beans and a side salad. Served in over-sized olive dishes, it doesn't look like a ton of food, but alas, is the perfect helping. The best part? It's CHEAP!

The restaurant itself is quirky, fun, and SMALL, so expect a wait. It's also unmarked (or at least subtly so) but keep looking around on the corner...it's there. And worth the search, AND the wait.

Just don't tell too many of your friends...let's keep this our little secret, shall we?
author: Aubrey S.

description:
Tiny place with a tiny cheap menu. One of the richest little atmospheres and friendly staff.

There are about five things you can get, such as samosas, empanadas, or fritatta. The food isn't out of this world, but it's enough for a little meal. Everything comes with beans, rice, and a little salad.

Only downside is they often close without warning, or close early because they're tired, or don't get around to picking up your check for fifteen minutes. This is a casual place in every respect. But I've had a first date there, and it went great.
author: Nick D.

description:
The food is good, not too much and great pricing. The place is small and cute but so very artistly done. owner operated and designed. Victor was a graphic artist that has painstakingly picked all the pieces up on the walls. There doesnt seem to be a square inch of space left to use. Everything is eye catching and interesting. 
I'm going back with my camera to take some photos. 
Do go and check this place out.
author: Virat R.

description:
I've been coming here for sangria since before it was trendy, and I have to say that I've got mixed feelings about the popularity it's been enjoying in the past year or two.

Of course, it's nice to see places I like become popular since the increased business will probably insulate them from getting driven out to make room for characterless boutiques, (like what happened to leather tongue) but I can't help but feel a little nostalgia for the days when the clientele was a little less hipsterish and it was always possible to get a seat fairly quickly. 

Weeknights still aren't so bad at least.
author: Matthew M.

description: I'd like to encourage any Minnesotans venturing to San Francisco to stop by Radio Habana Social Club.  Even if it's your first drink of the night you'll leave feeling a little uncertain, wondering what the hell WAS that??  The toy airplane dangling precariously from the ceiling had a baby doll head, and I saw Peewee at least once.  There may have been legs coming out of the wall.  This place is crazy in the best way.
author: Jillian C.

description:
i live in the neighborhood and have been walking by this place for some time with the best intentions of eating here, and finally got to last night. i'm a fan of cuban food (but no expert), though most of my experiences are from new york so maybe my expectations were off.

pros:

the obvious is the decor and charm of the space. lots of tschotskes adorning the walls to talk about if the convo ever takes a dull turn.

the woman who served us was incredibly sweet and had a very warm and welcoming smile. 

the sangria is really fantastic. it has some fruit but it's not full of it. i tend to enjoy the drink more than the fruit.

cons:

the food. there is a small selection on the menu, which i'm ok with, but for a cuban place i couldn't find any pork dishes. surprising but i was ok with it. the closest i got to pork was in the jambalaya special that came with some andouille sausage and shrimp. unfortunately this was unlike any jambalaya i've ever had and i've been to new orleans and have tried many different varieties.

the yellow rich had little flavor and was a bit dry. and the sauce seemed closer to spaghetti-os than anything made from whole tomatoes. it was edible, but not enjoyable. my girlfriend ordered it and i had to relinquish my chicken tamale since she couldn't handle the jambalaya.

the tamale was good, or at least what i got to eat of it. but not great. i'd be just as happy getting one from the tamale lady.

the plantains had a white cream (mayo?) sauce drizzled on top of them, which i haven't seen before. i wasn't a fan. they didn't need it as they were tasty as is. that's part of the joy of plantains. the simplicity of the dish.

other thoughts:

this is one of those spots that i WANT to love! i do! but the food is making it so hard and i've yet to satisfy my cuban itch since being in this city. 

i'd come here again for the sangria, but not the food. granted i'll try some more dishes before i write this place off. it's a small cozy space and i like that but i'd really wish they'd improve their menu.
author: craig s.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem. It's really small so a group of 4 is probably as big as you should attempt. 2 is better I would think.

The food is great - I've never been to Cuba but the menu seems to have a lot of Peruvian/South American influence and everything we had was really tasty and really reasonably priced.

The decor is straight out of a Tim Burton movie - conversation pieces abound.

When we first walked in there were a bunch of locals hanging out and my first thought was "Oh no, maybe it's too crowded and 'too' local." But there were a couple of small open tables in the back and we were immediately seated by a very friendly waitress. 

Within minutes I realized that this was the best kind of "local" place - where you have loyal customers who aren't territorial whatsoever and who welcome the newbies with open arms.
author: John Y.

description:
I'm not sure if the place is authentically Cuban, but it's authentically awesome, quirky, and a perfect place to go for a light dinner and a few rounds of their delicious, not-so-light sangria. (Delicious meaning it gets my vote for best sangria in the city, with a close runner-up of the Mission's Picaro tapas restaurant.) Although the few times I've been the staff hasn't been too keen on speaking English, they are still always very friendly and willing to make room for you in the cramped, zany dining room (I use the term loosely). Very San Francisco. I'd suggest if for any small group of friends that wants to get wonderfully inebriated and talk for hours, or -- even better -- for a new couple who just can't seem to get enough of one another's conversation. It's crampedness can be either romantic or intimate, provided the company is in good spirits. DON'T go here with a large group, or with anyone boring. 
I always get the sangria and the samosa dinner. It's satisfying. I have yet to try the fried plantains but that's probably even better (because how can anyone possibly mess up fried plantains...?).
author: Emily H.

description: Cozy, charming, excellent food and service with a home-cooked feel. I believe the owner is the chef! He's so unassuming. The decorations on the wall are mesmerizing.
author: Thomas S.

description:
I love unique places like Radio Havana
Decent food and wine with awesome art in the walls.
author: Ana R.

description: EXCELLENT, potent sangria.  menu too small, was hoping for a cuban or caribbean traditional, but tamale i had was decent.  nice low price.  space tiny but extraordinary (and ironically not overly conspicuous in its effort to be fascinating and cool).  they were playing fela loud.  i'd go again.
author: Jakeya C.

description:
Update 1/26/08

Back so soon you say?  Yes, and less than a week after my last visit I must revise my review in order to warn you of the fantastic danger that is the RHSC cheesecake.

Nicole + Miss P + Munchies = dangerous combination already, but little did we know what we were up against when we ordered this dessert.  First we started with a huge goblet of sangria and the delicious meatball dinner which comes with their awesome rice and beans and salad.  Well, the first sangria went down so well that we decided to share another...um, and another.  And when asked if we wanted dessert, we had no choice but to partake.  We shared a slice of the cheesecake. However, this is no ordinary cheesecake.  The cake is served on top of coconut syrup and heated ever so slightly.  This seemingly simple twist on the standard is actually absolutely mind-blowing!!  Warming the cake makes the cheese somewhat velvety which then oozes over the graham cracker crust that has absorbed the coconut syrup.  Collectively these elements produce a taste and texture that I've never experienced before.  It's just such a beautiful creation!  So wonderful in fact, that we had another slice!  Miss P and I definitely had an indulgent evening but I urge you to do the same and experience this cheesecake that will undoubtedly change and expand the flavors in life as you know it!

*************************************************

"Work like you don't need money,

Love like you've never been hurt,

Dance like no one's watching."

And Decorate like you just don't care!

You will never run out of things to look at while you sip your Sangria, grub on your meatballs, and bop to a variety of live music that comes through this tiny hole in the wall.  Every inch of wall space and most of the ceiling space is covered with the most random of random things that will make you go "Hmm" and "Ugh" and "Eew" and "Oh" and "OH MY!"  

Visit this inexpensive treasure trunk packed full of friendly hosts, comforting delicious food, fun sangria, exciting tunes, and a lively atmosphere!  There is very little space here but it's well worth a stop if you're able to find a spot to squeeze in amongst the craziness.
author: Nicole N.

description: This place gets four stars just for being so damn cool and entertaining. And for finally letting us come in one night after constantly walking past and seeing it closed. I've spent way too much time trying to peer into dusty windows here. So finally one night it happened. We were heading home after dinner and the lights were on and the door unlocked - yaaaayyyyyy!!!!! Didn't partake in any food but I don't really think the food is the point of being here - because the ambiance just rocks. I don't even care that the red wine I had was bad enough to make me choke, I'd go back in a heartbeat. And order sangria next time.
author: margot b.

description: One of the few places to get decent inexpensive food late at night in San Francisco. Small and unassuming, but do not underestimate.
author: Jaime B.

description: Worst place ever! Bad food, bad music, staff that is too busy socializing to do their job. Avoid this place!
author: Bob C.

description: Ian's a little harsh on this place, but I'll forgive him because his first name is my middle name. Just tried this place out for dinner, it was pretty good, the sangria being a highlight. I tried a chicken empanada, which came with basmati rice and black beans, nothing too fancy. The conversation and atmosphere are the real draws, at least worth a visit to check out the over-adorned, kitch-filled walls.
author: Nish N.

description: Sebastian's got it right - the food, while solid, is beside the point.  Great sangria and the surliest/nuttiest 'waitress' you're likely to find plus all manner of wacky art and random objects on the walls/ceiling/everywhere and what appear to be genuine marxists make this place one of my favorites.  Don't go there though, since I want a table when I'm there.
author: Scott C.

description: Love this place! Admittedly, I've only been here for drinks a few times (but definitely plan to return for a meal sometime soon), but it's such a great space with all the kitschy decor from floor to ceiling. It has such a relaxed vibe, making it a great place for a chill evening catching up with friends over drinks. And the prices can't be beat - two rounds of drinks for 4 people was a mere $24. Time to get your drink on!
author: Rachel G.

description:
step in for a glass of sangria and a plate of the albondigas or the tamales as a quick, cheap lite supper and you may get caught up and join the revolutionaries.
you almost feel as though you are interrupting the meeting, but it's okay if you're there to see whether you want to join or not.
look around, because there's lots to look at; just be respectful.  super kitschy.
hell, there's so much to look at....even after multiple visits, you should find something new that you didn't notice before.  everything on the walls is iconic and deep in meaning....or not.
one of my favorite places.  a reminder to keep my feet on the ground.
if you get the onion, you'll get this place.  it is a sanctuary.
author: Jackie C.

description: I get it. A neat hole in the wall, but there's nothing Cuban about this place. Anyone seeking out authetic Cuban stay away. There's no such thing as Cuban tappas.
author: Rey G.

description: Really unique atmosphere.   Really.  Thats why you come here, either for snacks or a pre/post dinner beverage.
author: chad n.

description: Besides Sangria one is hard put to find anything related to Cuba in this tiny restaurant/bar.  Seating maybe a dozen, the place is cramped and the food selection limited to four or five entrees.  If you are vegetarian you'll be having the Veggie plate which consist of a scoop of rice a tasty small salad and a samosa (Indian right?) or the Frittata (French?), which was good with the same tasty salad and scoop of rice.  The food was fair though even at only $7 a plate I expect a little more from SF restaurants.  In the end what I found I was paying for was not the small meal and steep sangria but the incredible atmosphere.  The place looks like single piece of art.  By all means, stop by, have a drink, and then go find some place up the street to eat.
author: Ian H.

description:
if the decor does not freak you out, you will enjoy this hole in the wall on Valencia Street.  The Sangria and empanadas are very good and the crowd is friendly.  This is a great place for a late night snack or to just drink with friends.

SFD
author: Peter H.

description:
My new favorite mission cafe to do work from.

One star for being spacious and having lots of desk workspace.

One star for not being overcrowded

One star for free FAST wireless

One star for taking credit cards

One star for friendly crew.
author: Matt T.

description:
There are a lot of 4 and 5 star reviews... I can see where you white people would be convinced that it is that good, but in all honesty, it really is A-Ok. 

Also a lot of the reviews seem to be on the decor and the sangria with very little mention of the food. I have had cuban food, this wasn't very cuban... It had a cuban flare to it I guess, but didn't remind me of cuba. They were small portions, which is fine... they weren't really small portions so much as real portions... I think a lot of people are too used to the giant chain restaurant portions that Cheese Cake Factory and Chilies provides. 

The menu, like the restaurant, is small and a bit of a mix-mash of flavors. The tamale, well, I don't know, it just looked out of place, maybe it needed the corn husk around it when served, which is a Cuban dish, tamales were brought over in the 1920-1950's, before the revolution. I am sure it was a mexican inspired dish, probably brought over when Cuba was a huge entertainment destination. 

A Samosa plate? Really? REALLY? I have never seen samosas on a cuban menu before. Maybe they really are on one, and I just have never seen it, maybe it is hidden in the whose who of cuban menus. No idea, but it just didn't seem very cuban to me. 

Both plates mentioned above were enjoyed by my friends who had ordered them. I ordered the empanada plate. I was very excited to see the empanadas on the menu. I had just seen the Hipster Olympics youtube video ( very funny http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAO4EVMlpwM) They said that empanadas are the new cup cake towards the end of the video, and I had a hankerin for empanadas for the rest of the day.... so yes, I was very excited to see empanadas on the menu. That was until the plate came out.  This wasn't an empanada.. Not any one i have seen before. This was a puff pastry of sorts... layers of dough wrapped into a neat little package... and the worst thing of this... IT WASN'T FRIED!!! So admittedly i was a little upset with Radio Haban Social Club for this. It also seems a bit stale. Looking in to the kitchen I see every thing being cooked in a toaster oven, the place is tiny, so I get it, but they sell small deep fat fryers. I have seen them on America's test kitchen, Christopher Kimball has done a review on them. They make small enough ones to fit inside the kitchen. The over all flavor wasn't too bad, like I mentioned the puff pasty it's self was a bit stale, but the green sauce on top made up for that. The plate has nice presentation. Pyramid of rice in a moat of black beans... The beans of some jalapenos cut into them which give it a nice spice. 

Here is the overall thing.. I didn't love my plate, but I didn't hate it. This is a good place to come and explore. Like mentioned in every other damn review, the walls are magically adorned with creepy barbie dolls and other junk. The sangria was sweet, I had a bit of a cold, so that is really all that came through on the sangria side. I would come back for the experience with new people. It is a fun place, but the food is eh. Leaving here I wanted real empanada's and I guess... a better take on cuban food. Maybe if they changed their name to Mission Social Club & Cafe I would be less disappointing by the not so cuban food they have, and take it as a little latin american cafe... I would probably give it 3 stars still, but then I wouldn't be a such a little bitch about it not being traditional cuban food. I'll be back. It was fun.
author: danny e.

description: Okay, for those of you who go there for the food, you are completely missing the point.  It's a place to get cozy with a love and whisper conspiracies while sipping sangrias, not a place to look for fine dining.  You are envoloped in kitch to a point where it's actually really cool.  I guarantee that you will see something new everytime you go there.  I am actually reluctant to give it such high praise since i really don't want too many people crowding me out of the little table near the back, next to the black-lit bathroom, under the floating crucified jesus...
author: Stephen D.

description: One of my favorite bars I've stumbled upon.  It's a tiny place with really cool people talking poetry, politics and music mostly in spanish.  When I went there was a cuban guitar player in the back and a bunch of people singing with him.  Very cozy, but if you're not culturally rich in the latin culture it's not a place for you.  Great decor which makes you feel like you're in a bar in Cuba, except for the Zappa poster, which I love.  Go there for the beer, sangria and to chill out with a few friends and locals.  It's not a pickup joint (there was one guy that hit on one of the people working there and almost got thrown out, it was interesting).
author: Mitch A.

description: I totally agree with you Angelica B. this is an original Valencia/Mission place that is still standing. All the new restaurants that have come and gone will never compare to this place. Every time I come there I run into somebody that I know or met having sangria there. I love that this place goes beyond the food it's about feeling like a community when you are in there. I guess people who comment negatively about this place have never felt that which is sad because if they would just give some places a chance they would feel that connection.
author: Natalia C.

description:
i definately don't feel cool enough for this place. i want to hang out there but... there's all these intensely interesting artists and musicians sitting around in this tiny beautiful toy-land drinking wine and laughing and the whole thing makes me very shy and probably much lamer than i am. 
when i asked if they had any food to snack on, like finger-food the waitress offered me soup and laughed warmly.
author: Sole A.

description: The decor is chaotic and visual overload with all sorts of figurines and photos and objects glued on the walls, mobiles hanging from the ceiling. It isn't for everyone, and is about the size of a postage stamp, but I loved it.  Besides, where else can you have a samosa with your sangria?
author: shoba d.

description:
about a year after i first bookmarked it and almost two years after i first noticed it on valencia, i finally tried out radio habana early this summer.

it was everything i'd hoped for.  alarmingly small, packed to the gills, teeming with junk, and brimming with odd conversation to be had.  i didn't have much by way of food (just nibbled at some of a friend's appetizers) and i'll have to second or third or fourth the watery sangria reviews, but vibe was totally quirky.

i sat at the bar and chatted with one of the owners during the meal.  we learned all about altered barbie and how they have one of the biggest hobbyist conventions in the city.  who knows what you'll learn if you visit?
author: Roshni R.

description: I passed by this place while it was closed once and was dying to come back and check it out - it definitely lived up to my expectations when it came to the atmosphere - go for the sangria and the entertaining character and friendly staff. But the the food ain't all that great - like could I please have more masa in my tamale??? (sarcasm).  And the beef empanada wasn't bad - I just wished there was a little more beef and less empanada. Since it's cheap, I guess you can afford to go down the street later to grab more grub if necessary, as my friends did.
author: Dalia K.

description: Based on the pictures, I thought this place sounded kind of gimmicky, but I was pleasantly surprised - it's actually a fun, cozy space, and the owners(?) couldn't have been nicer. I would say the food is more like a 3/5 - good, but not very memorable. Prices are reasonable.
author: Lorin M.

description: All the crazy stuff on the walls is the main draw to this place. The wait staff can be absentminded after a soccer game, so be prepared to wait if they forget your meal due to the excitement. Decent beans and rice for a take-out snack.
author: Shannon R.

description: Eclectic, cheap, good sangria, fun vibe. The samosas were especially tasty and I loved the look of the food - totally unexpected to get these long, glam plates with little dishes artfully arranged. Plus, the owner/chef looks like Santana, so that's entertaining to watch.
author: Beth T.

description:
great sangria. 
crazy decor.
COZY, really COZY.

good food.
author: Rosalee C.

description: It's hard not to get overwhelmed by the crazy-cool art, kitsch, and other objects on the wall.  Many repeat visits will be needed to take stock of everything...thankfully the food and sangria will make each trip worth it. This time out I had the tamal. Next time it'll be the empenada plate. It's tiny, so getting a table is all about luck of the draw.
author: dannebrog ..

description: The albondigos and El Salvadorean tamales are great, the sangria is smooth, but the real star here is the crazy artwork covering practically every square inch of the walls. Cash only, kids.
author: Maximillian M.

description: It's a fun little place -- TINY place -- with decent food. I went there one night and was treated to a Cuban music jam session.  I've also had poetry read to me and have engaged in some interesting political discussions I wasn't expecting.  Though they say they open at 7 sometimes it's not until 7:30 or 8, and they close at midnight.  They're closed Sunday when I need them the most!
author: Chilly M.

description: Radio Habana is a pretty small gaudy looking joint not everyone will appreciate but I really like this place.  It's not just about the great food, it's the experience you have while you're there that makes this place so good and fun.  A must get is their chicken tamal and their empanadas.... and they have beer on tap too!  Be warned though - they don't have much seating.
author: Julie K.

description: This place is great. It has a lot of charm and character. The staff was super friendly, and even the patrons were an interesting group. It feels like you have walked into a local cafe right in Cuba. The food selection isn't huge, but that's what makes this place great. It's simple but solid, good food. It's a tiny hole in the wall, with lots of chostskys hanging all over the place, so don't come with a group of more than 3, and make sure you know the hours. If you walk by at a random time during the day, it will most likely be closed.
author: S A.

description: This place gets points for uniqueness. It's uniquely small, uniquely decorated, and uniquely quaint for San Francisco. A strong contrast to the typical loud, crowded SF bar. I was a little freaked out by the slightly satanic/pornographic decor, but at least it's interesting. And their chai tea tastes like apple cinnamon!
author: Jenni L.

description: So it's not exactly gourmet but it is truly charming. More kitsch on the wall than you can imagine. One of those restaurants that you wonder why it exists but are glad that it does.
author: Patrick B.

description: Very cool, funky place. You could spend hours just staring at the walls here. Pretty much everything I could say has been said in reviews before. The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is the food was only mediocre. Then again, if you want a 5 star meal you probably shouldn't be eating at Radio Habana.  Still, the food was decent (and cheap).  One negative to my experience: my friend and I got to listen some dumb frat boy talk about puking the night before. Oh well, it's not RH's fault. Stick to the drinks & gazing at the decor & this place will be more than satisfying.
author: SL N.

description: Eccentric little place that attracts many an expat latino.  Good place to grab a beer (no frills, just order Negra Modelo) and take in the packrat decor.  The food is cheap and quiet good (had samosas and frittata). The staff is really friendly, attentive and warm.
author: Celeste A.

description: The albondigas were delish, the beer cold, the atmosphere warm and so was the service. Nothing bad to report on this place.
author: xxalex k.

description: Aka, Radio Habana Social Club, this spot is a terrific little hole in the wall.  Take your time when you're there, order an empanada or samosa, have a glass of sangria, and ponder the wonderous walls ornementation.  This is the kind of place that feels like Latin America - the pace is slow and the people are friendly.  While the name is Cuban, the food is an interesting mix (small menu, but good and with geometric presentation!).  If you order Sangria, two of the beret-wearing waiters that I've had actually slowly write out the full word on their pad of paper.  You have to ask for the bill, they don't bring it.  Word.
author: Mission D.

description: This place has character and is always full of local characters as well. On most nights you will find folks willing to debate politics and music. Being of a younger generation than most of its patrons my friends and I lovingly refer to it at times as "old man bar". However you don't let that scare you off...but also don't plan to meet your future husband here unless you are into older Latin Americans.
author: Emily C.

description: underwhelming. disinterested service. lights too bright. skip it.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: I unsuspectingly stumbled into this tiny restaurant while searching for food in the Mission in the wee hours. Though the kitchen was closed, I stayed as the waitress/hostess and a patron join the guitarist for an impromptu flamenco jam. A cup of toothpicks were her maracas, while the gentleman grabbed a stool to use as a drum. This place is almost magical in its romantic spontaneity.
author: Joshua D.

description: It's good to note that the name of this place includes the words "social club" rather than restaurant. It's perfectly fine and atmospheric for socializing. The art is the main attraction- it's absolutely bursting with it, and worth the trip alone. The food is limited and only ok. I'm pretty sure most of it is made in a toaster oven or microwave. The cheesecake was horrible- it had definitely been frozen and (mostly)thawed, but tasted worse than store-bought. If it's possible to get cheesecake from a vending machine, I think that's where they got theirs. We ate 2 bites of it and gave up. The waitress looked confused by that, but surely she's seen it before? The sangria was drinkable, but very sweet. I could barely taste the alcohol. I didn't try any of their other drinks- so maybe that's where they excel. The service was- well, I like to think they were trying to provide the type of service I've often seen in foreign countries where establishments sincerely want you to sit and drink and socialize and wouldn't dare bother you with a bill for fear of making you feel unwelcome. So, I'll give them the benefit of the doubt there. In summary- go once, for the experience, but once is probably all you really need.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Fascinating decor.  Interesting chef.  BEST RESTAURANT INTERIOR EVER.  Great location.  Soooo fun.  I could just sit and stare at all the stuff in here all day.  Jambalaya and plantains were delicious but a bit overpriced, and the portions were small.  The decor makes the prices worth it though.  It's an overall EXPERIENCE (not just food) that you're paying for with this place.  I will definitely come back here many times and recommend it to people - just for the wild decor!  Very limited hours.  I love that it's so small and cozy - only about 5 tables.  Oooh, and I love how it was all warm inside on a chilly night.  Quirky.  Memorable experience.
author: Tuesday J.

description: This place is a unique find among the many bars in the Mission. I like the intimate feel (small) and the informal hospitality (maybe only one or two people on staff). Unfortunately the things that I like about Radio Habana, also make it a bit of a tight squeeze for a party of over 2 or 3, and it can take a while to get your food/drink. The wall decor is outrageously weird, borderline frightening, so maybe keep young kids away (seriously- I mean dismembered dolls, etc). Still its a cute place, has a very cool vibe, almost a step into another country/time. I definitely recommend a visit, try the sangria!
author: Kika S.

description: I used to bring dates here all the time. The atmosphere is so rad! You can spend hours looking at the walls and still find new things. The outside is so covered with tchachkis that I didn't even know what the name of this place was for the longest time. They sell beer and wine from the bottle, and yummy cuban food. The tall waitress there is cool, and looks like a pirate.
author: Jenny Q.

description: i LOVE radio habana. from the kitschy decor to the tasty and inexpensive plates of deliciousness. the tasty cups of sangria. the funky locals and ever courteous servers. the "ambiance in a box" atmosphere. the spurts of live music once in a while. the apparent contrast from the slightly uppity atmosphere of Garcon next door. radio habana is a staple in my "must take my friend visiting from out of town" list. viva el radio habana!
author: ray e.

description:
this pretty much sums it up:
http://stretchyhead.com/?p=252
author: Ian T.

description: something about a creepy doll head stuck to an exterior wall makes me extremely hungry... even if you don't touch your plate you will leave here full - simply put a feast for eyes and tummy.
author: diana m.

description: great atmosphere, but the food was lacking a bit. i think everything is pre-cooked somewhere else and then just heated up there. but it wasn't too bad and it was dirt cheap! the real reason to come here is for the decor! it's nuts! the walls are completely covered in random shit. some funny, some clever, and some really creepy (the doll heads)!
author: James J.

description: my type of joint!  intimate, warm, exploding with character, full of regulars, always a party.  just wish they had a liquor license!
author: James R.

description: order a drink, sit down, soak it up.  this place just keeps on giving and giving.
author: Bernard W.

description: came here with Lenea M. and had us some goblets of sangria and a sturdy, figure it out and do it kinda conversation with my beloved mama L.  the place has all kinds of things to look at when youre getting reprimanded so you dont feel so bad when youre getting a talking to, especially with said goblet in hand.  anyhow it was a cool kitschy place that i would love to come back to for their southern american fare - the menu is pretty basic although the presentation is oddly modern on stark white rectangular plates, but it all goes down the same anyway.
author: Kimby T.

description: teeny place, fun for sangria and when you are bored with the usual. i'm looking forward to having a meal here next time, everything i saw coming out of the kitchen looked completely awesome. there's a ton of ephemera to look at on the walls, and the travelling mariachi band that came by made the night complete. you can't help but sing along, sort of.
author: Domenique B.

description: i've eyed this place for years, but i kept forgetting to go.  i went one evening around 10pm and was pleasantly surprised.  i split a vegetarian plate, which was small portions but very tasty.  i also got a glass of the sangria which was huge and very very good.  most of the time was spent looking around at the millions of things hanging from the ceilings and the walls.  it's very quaint and cozy and the food is excellent.  i just wish they had a few more vegetarian options-not that i mind getting what i got last time, again.
author: Kate W.

description: its ok for them to be dictator lovers! all dictators on there walls,let them swim in there heaven(s).
author: OSEPH E.

description: The food is good with a lively, comfortable atmosphere.  I don't need to comment on the decor but I would not suggest taking mushrooms and going inside.
author: pauline e.
